top_comment.text:
Hey mr. galaxy my cat has been kinda depressed lately.. She has a cone 
around her head because she keeps licking her fur away :I so I would ask 
How do I set her mood again? She is a really playful cat to begin with, we 
don't even need to buy toys for her! Heh she just finds things to play with 
all the time! Like pens, socks! She also goes trough my drawer and steals 
stuff just for fun I guess! That's why I love her so much! She has been 
like this since she was 1 month old I guess! Thank you mr. Galaxy :) please 
help may I ask politely! ~Katelyn﻿
top_comment.author: GamesWithKatelyn123

comments.text:

fur has fully grown, and he also said that she may have gone trough 
something traumatic.. And she has.. So it's not an allergy :)
comments.author: GamesWithKatelyn123

comments.text:
1 take the cone off you be depressed too with that on. 2 take the cat to 
the vet for an allergy test since that's 1 of the reasons cats overly groom 
themselves. And 3 try comfort zone. You can get it on amazon & any pet 
store.

she will be happily sitting on my backpack and she will be pissed and want

separation anxiety and whenever I come back she'll cuddle and be happy. She

so I put her on a leash and then walk her uptown with me most of the time. 
Purrs from Sassy Britches :)

comments.author: The 5th

comments.text:
Jackson Galaxy​, please, help me help my cat. She is my love and she's 
going to die if i can't help her. I'm desperate for your help. She's 
pissing blood and the vet did nothing. HOW DO I MAKE MY CAT DRINK WATER?

I play with her every day, she has mealtimes, she loves her daughter, they 
are both castrated and very happy. Still, she, Jasmine, refuses to drink

Help me please!
comments.author: Verónica Moscatel

comments.text:
I have noticed that when I'm out for more than a couple of hours (I'm 
mostly home all day), when I get home my four cats are a) all waiting for 
me in or around the house. I live in a rural area of the UK and they have 
free access to outdoors and one spends much of his time patrolling the 
fields hunting. b) they all follow me inside and start eating c) the one 
that spends the most time out in the fields hunting is the one that makes 
the biggest fuss about me being back home again. I've never considered all 
of this as separation anxiety, though I suppose it is, to a small degree, 
I've just thought they're relieved to see me back.
comments.author: Snowleopard755

comments.text:
I think my cat Mello has that. He is a social and tough cat, afraid of 
nothing (not even thunder/lightning or fireworks), except being alone. He 
is 1,5 yr old. When he was a little kitty (and I still had my other cat 
Jinx, 7yrs old), he followed me around the house, wanted to be near me at 
all times, even when I was in the toilet or shower. He would scratch my 
vinyl carpet and the door like his life depended on it and made crazy 
sounds like he was about to die. He also peed everywhere while I was at 
work.

He was neutred (?) when he was 6 months old. I took off the caps from the 
cat toilets and bought an extra cat toilet and that helped. When Jinx 
unexpectedly died, I decided to buy a new cat as a friend for Mello. A 2,5 
yr  Turkish Angora female. That went well for a while. But unfortunately, 
something happened, and they couldn't get along anymore. I tried everything 
possible, but eventually I had to find her a new home. Now it's just Mello 
and I and we are waiting for a new Turkish Angora male kitten <3

He still wants to be near me, but I managed to keep him out of the toilet 
once I'm in there. He doesn't cratch on the door anymore or make crazy 
noices, so that's a relief! The only thing he still does is scratching my 
vinyl carpet, which is damaged because of all the scratching. When he does 
that I open the door, far enough so he can see me, but not wide enouhg so 
he can come in. Sometimes I can close the door again. Then he just sits 
there in the hall way and waits for me to finish :)
comments.author: Elly Broek

comments.text:
My family says, that our cat always searchs for me when I'm not there for a 
few days. I live in my own flat now for one year. I visit my parents, when 
I have singing lessons... so he got used to this regular times, but in the 
summer holidays I didn't have singing lessons and didn't come regularly. he 
meowed on days, when I SHOULD be there, like "hey guys, something's wrong 
here!" XDD
Ah and as I was a child and was only away a week or at weekand, he was 
missing me (searching me in the house ans meowing) but when I was home 
again he looked at me and acted normal again, like I never was gone. Now, 
when I visit my parents, he is happy to see me and spends time with me. I 
think he has understood, that I'll go away again. I seem to be a special 
human to him. I was the only one allowing him to sleep with me in my bed, 
he even tried to teach me hunting mice XD  Awwwh I miss him a lot, it's so 
strange not living with a cat... I need my daily dose of cat-cuddling XD
comments.author: Nemokiddy

comments.text:
The first time I had to go on one week away (the family took care of him 
that time but he basically grew up with me) my cat was behaving veery 
strange. When I returned he was "meow-ing", running away, even scratching 
when I got close, like I was some stranger. I´m pretty sure he was shocked 
and angry but the behavior was strange nevertheless. Luckily later it 
turned back to normal although I have a sense he never forgot or forgived 
for it :(
comments.author: MarkaNLNL

comments.text:
Hi Darlene,
I'll try to help you if I can.
I just moved about a year ago. I have 3 cats, and this is what we did.
The day we moved in I put them in one of the bathrooms with a litter box, 
food, and a bed. Closed the door. Moved everything in, and later that day I 
opened the door and let them explore everything. It took a few days, but 
they didn't have any issues with the move. Just the moving of the litter 
box from my mom's bathroom to another part of the apartment, was the only 
thing. My girls don't go outside. But I have a big patio door and they love 
looking out of it watching the birds and the neighbors walk pass.
comments.author: Lisa R

comments.text:
Please Help! I am moving to a new home, just me and my 10yr old Himalayan 
Persian Cat Gizzy. It has just been us two for yrs. He is an indoor cat 
that just started going outside only in my small garden. He enjoys watching 
things go on, so long as they don't get close or no loud noises. How do I 
make the transition with him as smooth and stress free as possible? The new 
place will be bigger. He has always been skittish around people and loud 
noises, and will stay hidden for a while until he recognizes the visitors. 
I have a lot of health issues so I am in my bed quite often and he has 
adjusted to my quiet lifestyle. He's very mellow. I don't want him stress 
him during the move. He already see's there are changes with things being 
packed up and meows differently, and stays even closer to me. P.S, I didn't 
know how to post this so I just added to other comments?
comments.author: Darlene Hill

comments.text:
Yeah I have 3 Maine Coon mixes and my crier is my tuxedo she'll be 3 in 
September. I am taking care of my mom right now, she tells me about how bad 
Petunia gets. It's driving mom nuts. But what can I do about it.
comments.author: Lisa R

comments.text:
My 2 yr old tuxedo also has it bad too. I feel so guilty whenever I have to 
leave my baby alone.
comments.author: Judy Young

comments.text:
1 of mine does. All I have to do is take out the trash and she meows like 
crazy til I walk back in.

top_comment.text:
My cat is about 6 months old. I am having a nightmare trying to get her out 
on walks. Any advice.﻿
top_comment.author: megaladin 1

comments.text:
I walk both of my cats on the leash.  It took patience to train them, but 
it finally happened.  My male is the oldest and he would do the moon walk 
when the collar was put on.  My female would race around the room, over the 
couch and would hide back there.  Once they figured out that all this meant 
was they would go outside, they now let me know in an assorted ways.
comments.author: Carol Kesinger

comments.text:
I must add this:
Cats are indeed not like dogs. They can learn to leash-outings and enjoy 
them BUT never ever expect it to be like walking a dog!
Cats will not walk alongside you anywhere you want like a dog. My family 
had a cat before I was born. One day a homeless momma cat with a kitten 
walked into their kitchen through a window. They ended up keeping the 
kitten and a friend adopted the momma. The kitten grew up to a loving, 
social and veeeery patient boy (my sisters were 1 and 3 y.o when he moved 
in and would push the cat around in a dolly-pram etc). He was used to come 
and go as he pleased, no leash. He'd wait outside every morning and follow 
my mom all the way to kindergarten and back home a few meters behind her 
and the kids. 
That's the closest I've ever heard of cats going on actual walks.
Cats on a leash will set the pace and direction for your walks. You can 
pull a bit on the leash to turn her away from going into bushes etc where 
you can't go or the leash might tangle and to indicate a preferred 
direction.
But trying to control where she goes and a slower/faster pace too much will 
likely cause her to:
Lay down on her side refusing to walk/attempt to squirm out of her 
harness/hiss and growl, hunch down or jump to gtfo.
Also most cats like to stop and eat grass or lay in the sun, some never 
want to do anything else on walks but find a nice spot of grass and chill 
there.
Your cat will love to go out on a leash IF you do it right and have 
patience.
comments.author: Terhi Mäkinen

comments.text:
I disagree with prev responses!
Cats can totally enjoy walking on a leash and even demand it if they get 
used to it!
You have to do it on her terms and be patient though for it to work! Here's 
how:
1. Get her used to wearing the harness indoors. Then add leash.
2. Do not pull her out by the leash, either 
2.1 open the door and relax, let her get used to seeing and hearing the 
outdoors by the open door, harness and leash on. Let her set the pace she 
wants to go outside and how far/how long at a time to be out. This will 
eventually make her feel secure and comfortable to go on regular outings.
2.2 harness+leash on, pick her up and go outside, still holding her, and go 
a short distance from your door, (preferably so she doesn't see the door) 
to a spot that's quiet and calm. Minimal nearby traffic and people! Put her 
down, patch of grass is great, and sit down next to her. Be calm, speak 
with a soft, encouraging voice. If there's no sudden noises/movements to 
freak her out, she will begin to look around, sniff the air and what's 
close. Then she will take a few tentative steps and if it's still as 
calm/quiet soon she will be curiously exploring! 

I've tried both ways with different cats and have in mere hours gotten my 
indoor-cat loving leash-walks outside and after just 2-3 days with 1-3 15 
min walks (the first time will take min 2 hours of patience) they began 
expecting and demanding it by meowing at the door, getting excited just 
seeing the leash!
My dad has a 12 y.o indoor-cat he takes out on a leash twice everyday! His 
cat meows LOUDLY for his walks. When he's accidentally gotten out of his 
harness he's ran ahead to the door to wait for my dad.
comments.author: Terhi Mäkinen

comments.text:
Is there a reason that you're trying to take her out on walks? O.o Like, 
territorial issues or... just because? If it's "just because," I would 
suggest just letting her be. If she doesn't want to go out on the walks, 
don't make her. Dogs need to go outside in order to have space to exert all 
of their energy and take care of their business, cats don't. The poor thing 
probably just feels like you're tormenting her. 
HOWEVER, if you're trying to help her feel more in control of her 
territory, try positive association. Let her investigate the harness. 
Whenever you get her in harness (if possible), give her a treat. [:
comments.author: xohsodebonairex

comments.text:
Walks? Cats don't generally like going on walks like dogs do. Cats are very 
independent and like doing what they want on their terms.
comments.author: Henry Yuki

captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
I had a question.
Wookie is 15.
So he's a senior boy.

It seems to have coincided
with daylight savings time.

But he has started to have
a little bit of separation

anxiety when I go to
work, just simple things.

It's not when I'm
gone for a long time.

But any time I get my keys or
I'm getting ready to leave,
he knows my routine.
He comes to the door.

And sometimes even
when I come home,

he will be meowing
at the door, even
though it's not time for food.

Because he gets fed in
the morning and at night.

I've talked to my vet about
it and everything else
seems normal.
He's using the litter box.
He's eating normally.
We play every day.
Good.
He does his own thing.

And I've done things,
like I have a bird feeder.

I want things for him
to do when I'm not here.
Beautiful.

But I was wondering if
you had any other tips.

Because cats define
their lives by the sun

itself-- cats are
like sun dials, right?

At certain parts
of the day, they're

going to be in certain places
as the sun changes position.

Remember, the raw cat, the
cat that wakes up and says

I have to hunt, they're going
to be active at dawn and dusk.

Doesn't matter when the
sun goes up and goes down.
They'll be out there.
But here's the crazy part.

Because your circadian rhythm
changes with daylight savings

time, now we've got a cat who's
completely freaking confused.

Because the sun's saying
one thing and you're

saying something
else altogether.

So you guys were in concert
just a few weeks ago.
Now suddenly, everything's out.

When routine changes
for a cat, they're
not going to take it well.

So you're going to
see that mismatch.

What your job is, is to keep
that routine completely intact.

If you acquiesce
to him going, aah I

need you to do
something right now.

And you're like, OK fine,
fine, fine, fine, here you go.

Then you're keeping
them off balance.

Unfortunately,
it's like jet lag.

If you're in Paris yesterday
and you're in Madison

today, you're going to
wake up at 3 o'clock
in the morning wanting lunch.

And you've got to convince
yourself it ain't lunch time.
It's the middle the night.
Keep sleeping.

It's the same thing you're
going to tell your cat.
It's not time to eat right now.

It'll be time when the
sun starts going down.

And that's how we set
our clocks together.

The other thing in certain
separation anxiety,

a quick little tip, we
all tend to sort of do
this a little bit.

So the cat starts to
exhibit separation anxiety.
What do you do?

You start doing this
thing before you

leave the house, where
you're like, honey,
it's not a big deal.
It'll be a while.
It's not a big deal.

All the cat hears is,
what the hell's going on.
What's a big deal?
It's a big deal.
That's all they hear.
Blank, blank, blank, big deal.

You're treating them differently
which feeds into the fear
itself.
A couple of things you can do.

Switch up your routine just
a little bit in the morning.

Your cat, if he has
separation anxiety,

knows what it means
when you pick up
your keys off the table.
He knows what that means.
He knows you're leaving.

So you pick up your
keys five minutes

after you wake up and
put them in your pocket,
then you hang out for an hour.
Do you know what I mean?

You feed him right
before you leave.

The next day, right
when you wake up.

You make sure you're keeping
that schedule just a little
bit off.

So then when you
go to leave, you

can just leave and not
make a big deal out if it.

So on thing is
switch up schedule.

Second thing is don't make a big
deal when you leave the house.

Third thing is give
him a little something
to do while you're leaving.

So I know you were
saying you have cat TV.

You have bird houses
and stuff like that.

Your best friend
could be a puzzle toy.

Even those little
balls, the puzzle balls.
Put a couple of treats in there.

The only time he gets those
kind of jack-pot type treats

is when it's in
that puzzle ball.

Again, you're switching this up
five minutes before you leave,

right when you leave,
10 minutes before.
And you put out the ball.
He's playing with it.
He's getting treats.

And he's enjoying himself
and you're out the door.
Don't say bye.
I know that sounds weird.
Don't say bye.
Don't say you'll be back soon.
None of that.
Just walk out.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Does My Cat Have Separation Anxiety?
